trans-unit.source: Constructing filter strings for the table designer
trans-unit.target: Constructing filter strings for the table designer

trans-unit.source: Constructing filter strings for the table designer
trans-unit.target: Constructing filter strings for the table designer

trans-unit.source: To filter data in an Azure table that is displayed in the Visual Studio Table Designer, you construct a filter string and enter it into the filter field.
trans-unit.target: To filter data in an Azure table that is displayed in the Visual Studio Table Designer, you construct a filter string and enter it into the filter field.

trans-unit.source: The filter string syntax is defined by the WCF Data Services and is similar to a SQL WHERE clause, but is sent to the Table service via an HTTP request.
trans-unit.target: The filter string syntax is defined by the WCF Data Services and is similar to a SQL WHERE clause, but is sent to the Table service via an HTTP request.

trans-unit.source: The Table Designer handles the proper encoding for you, so to filter on a desired property value, you need only enter the property name, comparison operator, criteria value, and optionally, Boolean operator in the filter field.
trans-unit.target: The Table Designer handles the proper encoding for you, so to filter on a desired property value, you need only enter the property name, comparison operator, criteria value, and optionally, Boolean operator in the filter field.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to include the $filter query option as you would if you were constructing a URL to query the table via the <linkText>Storage Services REST API Reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to include the $filter query option as you would if you were constructing a URL to query the table via the <linkText>Storage Services REST API Reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The WCF Data Services are based on the <linkText>Open Data Protocol</linkText><title></title> (OData).
trans-unit.target: The WCF Data Services are based on the <linkText>Open Data Protocol</linkText><title></title> (OData).

trans-unit.source: For details on the filter system query option ($filter), see the OData URI Conventions specification.
trans-unit.target: For details on the filter system query option ($filter), see the OData URI Conventions specification.

trans-unit.source: The following logical operators are supported for all property types:
trans-unit.target: The following logical operators are supported for all property types:

trans-unit.source: Logical operator
trans-unit.target: Logical operator

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Example filter string
trans-unit.target: Example filter string

trans-unit.source: eq
trans-unit.target: eq

trans-unit.source: Equal
trans-unit.target: Equal

trans-unit.source: City eq 'Redmond'
trans-unit.target: City eq 'Redmond'

trans-unit.source: gt
trans-unit.target: gt

trans-unit.source: Greater than
trans-unit.target: Greater than

trans-unit.source: Price gt 20
trans-unit.target: Price gt 20

trans-unit.source: ge
trans-unit.target: ge

trans-unit.source: Greater than or equal to
trans-unit.target: Greater than or equal to

trans-unit.source: Price ge 10
trans-unit.target: Price ge 10

trans-unit.source: lt
trans-unit.target: lt

trans-unit.source: Less than
trans-unit.target: Less than

trans-unit.source: Price lt 20
trans-unit.target: Price lt 20

trans-unit.source: le
trans-unit.target: le

trans-unit.source: Less than or equal
trans-unit.target: Less than or equal

trans-unit.source: Price le 100
trans-unit.target: Price le 100

trans-unit.source: ne
trans-unit.target: ne

trans-unit.source: Not equal
trans-unit.target: Not equal

trans-unit.source: City ne 'London'
trans-unit.target: City ne 'London'

trans-unit.source: and
trans-unit.target: and

trans-unit.source: And
trans-unit.target: And

trans-unit.source: Price le 200 and Price gt 3.5
trans-unit.target: Price le 200 and Price gt 3.5

trans-unit.source: or
trans-unit.target: or

trans-unit.source: Or
trans-unit.target: Or

trans-unit.source: Price le 3.5 or Price gt 200
trans-unit.target: Price le 3.5 or Price gt 200

trans-unit.source: not
trans-unit.target: not

trans-unit.source: Not
trans-unit.target: Not

trans-unit.source: not isAvailable
trans-unit.target: not isAvailable

trans-unit.source: When constructing a filter string, the following rules are important:
trans-unit.target: When constructing a filter string, the following rules are important:

trans-unit.source: Use the logical operators to compare a property to a value.
trans-unit.target: Use the logical operators to compare a property to a value.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is not possible to compare a property to a dynamic value; one side of the expression must be a constant.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is not possible to compare a property to a dynamic value; one side of the expression must be a constant.

trans-unit.source: All parts of the filter string are case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: All parts of the filter string are case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: The constant value must be of the same data type as the property in order for the filter to return valid results.
trans-unit.target: The constant value must be of the same data type as the property in order for the filter to return valid results.

trans-unit.source: For more information about supported property types, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about supported property types, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When you filter on string properties, enclose the string constant in single quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: When you filter on string properties, enclose the string constant in single quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: The following example filters on the PartitionKey and RowKey properties; additional non-key properties could also be added to the filter string:
trans-unit.target: The following example filters on the PartitionKey and RowKey properties; additional non-key properties could also be added to the filter string:

trans-unit.source: You can enclose each filter expression in parentheses, although it is not required:
trans-unit.target: You can enclose each filter expression in parentheses, although it is not required:

trans-unit.source: Note that the Table service does not support wildcard queries, and they are not supported in the Table Designer either.
trans-unit.target: Note that the Table service does not support wildcard queries, and they are not supported in the Table Designer either.

trans-unit.source: However, you can perform prefix matching by using comparison operators on the desired prefix.
trans-unit.target: However, you can perform prefix matching by using comparison operators on the desired prefix.

trans-unit.source: The following example returns entities with a LastName property beginning with the letter 'A':
trans-unit.target: The following example returns entities with a LastName property beginning with the letter 'A':

trans-unit.source: To filter on an integer or floating-point number, specify the number without quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: To filter on an integer or floating-point number, specify the number without quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: This example returns all entities with an Age property whose value is greater than 30:
trans-unit.target: This example returns all entities with an Age property whose value is greater than 30:

trans-unit.source: This example returns all entities with an AmountDue property whose value is less than or equal to 100.25:
trans-unit.target: This example returns all entities with an AmountDue property whose value is less than or equal to 100.25:

trans-unit.source: To filter on a Boolean value, specify true or false without quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: To filter on a Boolean value, specify true or false without quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: The following example returns all entities where the IsActive property is set to true:
trans-unit.target: The following example returns all entities where the IsActive property is set to true:

trans-unit.source: You can also write this filter expression without the logical operator.
trans-unit.target: You can also write this filter expression without the logical operator.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the Table service will also return all entities where IsActive is true:
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the Table service will also return all entities where IsActive is true:

trans-unit.source: To return all entities where IsActive is false, you can use the not operator:
trans-unit.target: To return all entities where IsActive is false, you can use the not operator:

trans-unit.source: To filter on a DateTime value, specify the datetime keyword, followed by the date/time constant in single quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: To filter on a DateTime value, specify the datetime keyword, followed by the date/time constant in single quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: The date/time constant must be in combined UTC format, as described in <linkText>Formatting DateTime Property Values</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The date/time constant must be in combined UTC format, as described in <linkText>Formatting DateTime Property Values</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following example returns entities where the CustomerSince property is equal to July 10, 2008:
trans-unit.target: The following example returns entities where the CustomerSince property is equal to July 10, 2008:
